Contents:


\chapter{Short description}
\label{intro:welcome-to-syntax-diagram-generator-s-documentation}\label{intro:short-description}\label{intro::doc}
Syntax Diagram Generator is an application written in Python which converts definition of diagram (in structured form) to SVG and PNG image(s).


\chapter{Installation}
\label{installation:installation}\label{installation::doc}
Before start using Syntax Diagram Generator, user should assure that specific libraries and packages have been installed in a operation system:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
setuptools (\href{http://pypi.python.org/pypi/setuptools}{http://pypi.python.org/pypi/setuptools})

\item {} 
pysvg (\href{http://pypi.python.org/pypi/pysvg/0.2.1}{http://pypi.python.org/pypi/pysvg/0.2.1})

\item {} 
CairoSVG (\href{http://cairosvg.org/}{http://cairosvg.org/})

\item {} 
python-tk (\href{http://wiki.python.org/moin/TkInter}{http://wiki.python.org/moin/TkInter})

\end{itemize}

After satisfy these assumptions, installation of Syntax Diagram Generator is executing the command:

\code{python setup.py install}


\chapter{Running an application}
\label{running:running-an-application}\label{running::doc}
To get diagrams, an appriopriate Python file should be prepared:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} -*- coding: utf-8 -*-}
\PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n+nn}{sys}
\PYG{n}{sys}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{path}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{append}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s}{'}\PYG{l+s}{.}\PYG{l+s}{'}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{sdgen.svg} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{o}{*}

\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{}definition of diagram}
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{}examples will appear in the next chapter}
\PYG{n}{data} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{o}{.}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{o}{.}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}

\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{}a second parameter tells about directory}
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{}to write all diagrams}
\PYG{n}{result} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{as\PYGZus{}svg}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{data}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{argv}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{}printing resulting main image}
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{}first index - number of image}
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{}second index - 0 for name, 1 for data}
\PYG{k}{print} \PYG{n}{result}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{encode}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s}{'}\PYG{l+s}{utf-8}\PYG{l+s}{'}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{Verbatim}

Then generating a image (or images) is executing a command:

\code{python examples/inputfile.py directory \textgreater{} outputimage.svg}

All images will be deployed into the specified directory and the main image into \code{outputimage.svg} file.


\chapter{Examples}
\label{examples::doc}\label{examples:examples}
Below there are some examples of using Syntax Diagram Generator to generate images.

\PYG{n}{sys}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{path}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{append}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s}{'}\PYG{l+s}{.}\PYG{l+s}{'}\PYG{p}{)}

    \PYG{l+s}{"}\PYG{l+s}{view}\PYG{l+s}{"}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s}{"}\PYG{l+s}{Group}\PYG{l+s}{"}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{l+s}{"}\PYG{l+s}{name}\PYG{l+s}{"}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s}{"}\PYG{l+s}{Example of Return}\PYG{l+s}{"}\PYG{p}{,}

        \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{l+s}{"}\PYG{l+s}{view}\PYG{l+s}{"}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s}{"}\PYG{l+s}{Terminal}\PYG{l+s}{"}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s}{"}\PYG{l+s}{value}\PYG{l+s}{"}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s}{"}\PYG{l+s}{A}\PYG{l+s}{"}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{,}
        \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
             \PYG{l+s}{"}\PYG{l+s}{children}\PYG{l+s}{"} \PYG{p}{:} \PYG{p}{[}
                        \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}

\PYG{n}{result} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{as\PYGZus{}svg}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{data}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{sys}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{argv}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{k}{print} \PYG{n}{result}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{encode}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s}{'}\PYG{l+s}{utf-8}\PYG{l+s}{'}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{Verbatim}
